terms.definition: A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or files over time, allowing users to see what changed, when, and by whom.
A chronological record of all changes, access, and activities performed on documents or systems, used for compliance and accountability purposes.
The use of software to automatically execute business processes and tasks based on predefined rules, reducing manual intervention.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted online and accessed via web browsers.
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems.
The systematic organization, storage, and retrieval of digital documents in a centralized platform for easy access and control.
The ability to generate and view data reports instantly as information is updated, providing current insights without delays.
The systematic analysis of data to identify patterns, trends, and insights that inform decision-making and performance improvement.
The systematic monitoring and documentation of adherence to regulatory requirements, standards, and internal policies.
Occupational Safety and Health Administration - the U.S. federal agency responsible for enforcing workplace safety and health standards.
Environmental Protection Agency - the U.S. federal agency responsible for protecting human health and the environment through regulation enforcement.
Personal Protective Equipment - specialized clothing or equipment worn by workers to protect against health and safety hazards.
A single, unified system that consolidates multiple functions, data, and tools in one accessible location for streamlined management.
Software features that enable multiple users to work together, share information, and communicate effectively within a platform.
The systematic process of identifying, analyzing, and evaluating potential hazards and their likelihood of causing harm in the workplace.
